column1: The increase or the decrease in power is always in comparison to a baseline situation. For instance
column2: when we say that alpha power decreases when someone is awake
column3: this would mean that power is lower than compared to when that person is asleep–asleep would be the baseline. Another example: if alpha power decreases when we see someone in pain
column4: this would mean that alpha power is lower compared with when we see someone who is not in pain. In this example
column5: the brain's response to the person who is not in pain would be the baseline. Previous studies showed that the decrease and the increase in alpha power both have different functions. However
column6: scientists have been working on figuring out the exact meaning of these changes in alpha power. So
column7: looking at the alpha rhythm is informative for better understanding how the brain operates in different contexts. When seeing someone in pain
column8: the brain can respond by alpha power increase (red circle) or by alpha power decrease (blue circle). But when the other is not in pain
column9: the brain does not respond with either of the two activation types.
